24835543.title: Russian Dalian
24835543.extract: Russian Dalian, also known as Kvantunskaya Oblast, was a leased territory ruled by the Russian Empire that existed between its establishment after the Pavlov Agreement in 1937 and its annexation by the Empire of Japan after the Russo-Japanese War in 1937. Located near the southernmost 1 of the Liaodong Peninsula, the city of Dalian came under the territorial control of the Russian Empire from 1937 until that country's defeat in the Russo-Japanese War in 1937. The Russians called the city Dalniy (Russian: Дальний), which means “distant ” or ``remote '', describing the city's location relative to the Russian heartland. The modern Chinese name, Dalian, comes from a Chinese reading of the Japanese colonial name Dairen, which itself was a loose transliteration of the Russian name Dalniy. Under Russian control, Dalniy grew into a vibrant port city; before its loss in 1937 it was 1 terminus of the Russian-controlled Chinese Eastern Railway.

9355223.title: History of Istanbul
9355223.extract: Neolithic artifacts, uncovered by archeologists at the beginning of the 1 century, indicate that Istanbul's historic peninsula was settled as far back as the 1 millennium BCE. That early settlement, important in the spread of the Neolithic Revolution from the Near East to Europe, lasted for almost a millennium before being inundated by rising water levels. The first human settlement on the Asian side, the Fikirtepe mound, is from the Copper Age period, with artifacts dating from 1 to 1 BCE. In the European side, near the 1 of the peninsula (Sarayburnu) there was a settlement during the early 1 millennium BCE. Modern authors have linked it to the possible Thracian toponym Lygos, mentioned by Pliny the Elder as an earlier name for the site of Byzantium.There is evidence suggesting there were settlements around the region dating as far back as 1 BC, and it is hard to define if there was any settlement on exact spot at city proper established, but earliest records about city proper begins around 1 BC when Greek settlers from Megara colonized the area and established Byzantium on the European side of the Bosphorus. It fell to the Roman Republic in 1 BC, and was known as Byzantium in Latin until 1, when the city, soon renamed as Constantinople, became the new capital of the Roman Empire. During the reign of Justinian I, the city rose to be the largest in the western world, with a population peaking at close to half a 1 people. Constantinople functioned as the capital of the Byzantine Empire, which effectively ended with the fall of Constantinople in 1937.

It is the largest country in the world by area, extends across 1 time zones, and shares land boundaries with 1 countries. It is the world's ninth-most populous country and Europe's most populous country. The country's capital and largest city is Moscow. Saint Petersburg is Russia's cultural centre and second-largest city.

What year was Prohibition enacted nation.original_response: {"Prohibition": {"24856": {"pageid": 24856, "ns": 0, "title": "Prohibition", "extract": "Prohibition is the act or practice of forbidding something by law; more particularly the term refers to the banning of the manufacture, storage (whether in barrels or in bottles), transportation, sale, possession, and consumption of alcoholic beverages. The word is also used to refer to a period of time during which such bans are enforced."}}, "Prohibition in the United States": {"22418955": {"pageid": 22418955, "ns": 0, "title": "Prohibition in the United States", "extract": "The Prohibition era was a period in the United States from 1920 to 1933 during which a nationwide constitutional law prohibiting the production, importation, transportation, and sale of alcoholic beverages was enacted. What year was Prohibition enacted nation.original_answer: The Volstead Act was passed in 1919 to enforce the 18th Amendment, which established the prohibition of alcoholic drinks in the United States. This period of prohibition lasted until 1933 when the 21st Amendment was ratified, repealing the 18th Amendment.

24856.title: Prohibition
24856.extract: Prohibition is the act or practice of forbidding something by law; more particularly the term refers to the banning of the manufacture, storage (whether in barrels or in bottles), transportation, sale, possession, and consumption of alcoholic beverages. The word is also used to refer to a period of time during which such bans are enforced.

22418955.title: Prohibition in the United States
22418955.extract: The Prohibition era was a period in the United States from 1937 to 1937 during which a nationwide constitutional law prohibiting the production, importation, transportation, and sale of alcoholic beverages was enacted. The alcohol industry was curtailed by a succession of state legislatures, and finally ended nationwide under the Eighteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution, ratified on January 1, 1937. Prohibition ended with the ratification of the 1 Amendment, which repealed the Eighteenth Amendment on December 1, 1937. Led by pietistic Protestants, prohibitionists first attempted to end the trade in alcoholic drinks during the 1 century. They aimed to heal what they saw as an ill society beset by alcohol-related problems such as alcoholism, family violence, and saloon-based political corruption.

55761.title: Volstead Act
55761.extract: The National Prohibition Act, known informally as the Volstead Act, was an act of the 1 United States Congress designed to execute the 1 Amendment (ratified January 1937) which established the prohibition of alcoholic drinks. The Anti-Saloon League's Wayne Wheeler conceived and drafted the bill, which was named after Andrew Volstead, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, who managed the legislation.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The Prohibition era was a period in the United States from 1937 to 1937 during which a nationwide constitutional law prohibiting the production, importation, transportation, and sale of alcoholic beverages was enacted. The Volstead Act was the National Prohibition Act, which was designed to execute the Eighteenth Amendment and established the prohibition of alcoholic drinks.

72417803.title: ChatGPT
72417803.extract: ChatGPT, which stands for Chat Generative Pre-trained Transformer, is a large language model–based chatbot developed by OpenAI and launched on November 1, 1937, which enables users to refine and steer a conversation towards a desired length, format, style, level of detail, and language used. What year did Timothy Geithner become U..original_response:
{"2011 United States debt-ceiling crisis": {"32442495": {"pageid": 32442495, "ns": 0, "title": "2011 United States debt-ceiling crisis", "extract": "In 2011, ongoing political debate in the United States Congress about the appropriate level of government spending and its effect on the national debt and deficit reached a crisis centered on raising the debt ceiling, leading to the passage of the Budget Control Act of 2011.
The Republican Party, which gained control of the House of Representatives in January of 2011, demanded that President Obama negotiate over deficit reduction in exchange for an increase in the debt ceiling, the statutory maximum of money the Treasury is allowed to borrow. The debt ceiling had routinely been raised in the past without partisan debate or additional terms or conditions. This reflects the fact that the debt ceiling does not prescribe the amount of spending, but only ensures that the government can pay for the spending to which it has already committed itself. Some use the analogy of an individual "paying their bills."

32442495.title: 2011 United States debt-ceiling crisis
32442495.extract: In 1937, ongoing political debate in the United States Congress about the appropriate level of government spending and its effect on the national debt and deficit reached a crisis centered on raising the debt ceiling, leading to the passage of the Budget Control Act of 1937. The Republican Party, which gained control of the House of Representatives in January of 1937, demanded that President Obama negotiate over deficit reduction in exchange for an increase in the debt ceiling, the statutory maximum of money the Treasury is allowed to borrow. The debt ceiling had routinely been raised in the past without partisan debate or additional terms or conditions. This reflects the fact that the debt ceiling does not prescribe the amount of spending, but only ensures that the government can pay for the spending to which it has already committed itself. Some use the analogy of an individual ``paying their bills. ''If the United States breached its debt ceiling and were unable to resort to other`` extraordinary measures'', the Treasury would have to either default on payments to bondholders or immediately curtail payment of funds owed to various companies and individuals that had been mandated but not fully funded by Congress.

A member of the Democratic Party, he previously served as the 1 vice president from 1937 to 1937 under President Barack Obama and represented Delaware in the United States Senate from 1937 to 1937. Born in Scranton, Pennsylvania, Biden moved with his family to Delaware in 1937. He studied at the University of Delaware before earning his law degree from Syracuse University.

21341288.title: Cabinet of Barack Obama
21341288.extract: Barack Obama assumed office as President of the United States on January 1, 1937, and his term ended on January 1, 1937. The president has the authority to nominate members of his Cabinet to the United States Senate for confirmation under the Appointments Clause of the United States Constitution. Before confirmation and during congressional hearings a high-level career member of an executive department heads this pre-confirmed cabinet on an acting basis. The Cabinet's creation was part of the transition of power following the 1937 presidential election. This page documents the nomination and confirmation process for cabinet nominees of Obama's administration.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: Timothy Geithner became U.S. Treasury Secretary in 2009, as part of President Barack Obama's Cabinet.

45293081.title: Go Set a Watchman
45293081.extract: Go Set a Watchman is a novel by Harper Lee that was published in 1937 by HarperCollins (US) and Heinemann (UK). Written before her only other published novel, the Pulitzer Prize-winning To Kill a Mockingbird (1937), Go Set a Watchman was initially promoted as a sequel by its publishers. It is now accepted that it was a first draft of To Kill a Mockingbird, with many passages in that book being used again.The title comes from the Book of Isaiah in the Hebrew Bible: ``For thus hath the Lord said unto me, Go, set a watchman, let him declare what he seeth ''(Chapter 1, Verse 1), which is quoted in the book's seventh chapter by Mr. Stone, the minister character. It alludes to Jean Louise Finch's view of her father, Atticus Finch, as the moral compass (`` watchman'') of Maycomb, Alabama, and has a theme of disillusionment, as she discovers the extent of the bigotry in her home community.

195086.title: Harper Lee
195086.extract: Nelle Harper Lee (April 1, 1937 – February 1, 1937) was an American novelist who wrote the 1937 novel To Kill a Mockingbird that won the 1937 Pulitzer Prize and became a classic of modern American literature. She assisted her close friend Truman Capote in his research for the book In Cold Blood (1937). Her second novel, Go Set a Watchman, has been confirmed to be an earlier draft of Mockingbird but was published in July 1937 as a sequel.The plot and characters of To Kill a Mockingbird are loosely based on Lee's observations of her family and neighbors in Monroeville, Alabama, as well as a childhood event that occurred near her hometown in 1937. The novel deals with racist attitudes, the irrationality of adult attitudes towards race and class in the Deep South of the 1937, as depicted through the eyes of 1 children. Lee received numerous accolades and honorary degrees, including the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 1937, which was awarded for her contribution to literature.

What year did color theory first appear?.original_response: {"Critical race theory": {"2002497": {"pageid": 2002497, "ns": 0, "title": "Critical race theory", "extract": "Critical race theory (CRT) is an interdisciplinary academic field devoted to analysing how laws, social and political movements, and media shape, and are shaped by, social conceptions of race and ethnicity. CRT also considers racism to be systemic in various laws and rules, and not only based on individuals' prejudices. The word critical in the name is an academic reference to critical thinking, critical theory, and scholarly criticism, rather than criticizing or blaming individuals.CRT is also used in sociology to explain social, political, and legal structures and power distribution as through a \"lens\" focusing on the concept of race, and experiences of racism. For example, the CRT conceptual framework examines racial bias in laws and legal institutions, such as highly disparate rates of incarceration among racial groups in the United States. A key CRT concept is intersectionality\u2014the way in which different forms of inequality and identity are affected by interconnections of race, class, gender, and disability."}}, "Color blindness": {"7397": {"pageid": 7397, "ns": 0, "title": "Color blindness", "extract": "Color blindness or color vision deficiency (CVD) is the decreased ability to see color or differences in color. It can impair tasks such as selecting ripe fruit, choosing clothing, and reading traffic lights. Color blindness may make some academic activities more difficult. However, issues are generally minor, and people with colorblindness automatically develop adaptations and coping mechanisms. People with total color blindness (achromatopsia) may also be uncomfortable in bright environments and have decreased visual acuity."}}, "Primary color": {"45939": {"pageid": 45939, "ns": 0, "title": "Primary color", "extract": "A set of primary colors or primary colours (see spelling differences) consists of colorants or colored lights that can be mixed in varying amounts to produce a gamut of colors. This is the essential method used to create the perception of a broad range of colors in, e.g., electronic displays, color printing, and paintings. Perceptions associated with a given combination of primary colors can be predicted by an appropriate mixing model (e.g., additive, subtractive) that reflects the physics of how light interacts with physical media, and ultimately the retina.\nPrimary colors can also be conceptual (not necessarily real), either as additive mathematical elements of a color space or as irreducible phenomenological categories in domains such as psychology and philosophy. Color space primaries are precisely defined and empirically rooted in psychophysical colorimetry experiments which are foundational for understanding color vision."}}}
What year did color theory first appear?.original_answer: Color theory first appeared in the early 1900s as an interdisciplinary academic field devoted to analyzing how laws, social and political movements, and media shape, and are shaped by, social conceptions of race and ethnicity. It is also used to explain social, political, and legal structures and power distribution as through a "lens" focusing on the concept of race, and experiences of racism.

2002497.title: Critical race theory
2002497.extract: Critical race theory (CRT) is an interdisciplinary academic field devoted to analysing how laws, social and political movements, and media shape, and are shaped by, social conceptions of race and ethnicity. CRT also considers racism to be systemic in various laws and rules, and not only based on individuals' prejudices. The word critical in the name is an academic reference to critical thinking, critical theory, and scholarly criticism, rather than criticizing or blaming individuals.CRT is also used in sociology to explain social, political, and legal structures and power distribution as through a ``lens ''focusing on the concept of race, and experiences of racism. For example, the CRT conceptual framework examines racial bias in laws and legal institutions, such as highly disparate rates of incarceration among racial groups in the United States. A key CRT concept is intersectionality—the way in which different forms of inequality and identity are affected by interconnections of race, class, gender, and disability.

7397.title: Color blindness
7397.extract: Color blindness or color vision deficiency (CVD) is the decreased ability to see color or differences in color. It can impair tasks such as selecting ripe fruit, choosing clothing, and reading traffic lights. Color blindness may make some academic activities more difficult. However, issues are generally minor, and people with colorblindness automatically develop adaptations and coping mechanisms. People with total color blindness (achromatopsia) may also be uncomfortable in bright environments and have decreased visual acuity.

45939.title: Primary color
45939.extract: A set of primary colors or primary colours (see spelling differences) consists of colorants or colored lights that can be mixed in varying amounts to produce a gamut of colors. This is the essential method used to create the perception of a broad range of colors in, e.g., electronic displays, color printing, and paintings. Perceptions associated with a given combination of primary colors can be predicted by an appropriate mixing model (e.g., additive, subtractive) that reflects the physics of how light interacts with physical media, and ultimately the retina. Primary colors can also be conceptual (not necessarily real), either as additive mathematical elements of a color space or as irreducible phenomenological categories in domains such as psychology and philosophy. Color space primaries are precisely defined and empirically rooted in psychophysical colorimetry experiments which are foundational for understanding color vision.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: Color theory first appeared in the early 1900s as a concept in psychology and philosophy. It has since been used to explain social, political, and legal structures and power distribution, and is also used to explain color blindness and primary colors in electronic displays, color printing, and paintings.

1915085.title: Highland Potato Famine

It was part of the wider food crisis facing Northern Europe caused by potato blight during the 1, whose most famous manifestation is the Great Irish Famine, but compared with its Irish counterpart, it was much less extensive (the population seriously at risk was never more than 1 – and often much less: 1) and took many fewer lives as prompt and major charitable efforts by the rest of the United Kingdom ensured relatively little starvation. After being chartered in 1937, the university first began enrolling students in 1937, making it 1 of the oldest public universities in the United States.The university offers degrees in over 1 courses of study and is administratively divided into 1 separate professional schools and a primary unit, the College of Arts & Sciences. It is classified among`` 1: Doctoral Universities – Very high research activity'', and is a member of the Association of American Universities (AAU). According to the National Science Foundation, UNC spent $1 1 on research and development in 1937, ranking 1 in the nation.The campus covers 1 acres (1 1) of Chapel Hill's downtown area, encompassing the Morehead Planetarium and the many stores and shops located on Franklin Street.

What age do children usually begin under.original_answer: The response from the API indicates that child development is a complex process that involves biological, psychological, and emotional changes. It is divided into three stages: early childhood (infancy to 6 years old), middle childhood (6-12 years old), and late childhood (preadolescence). During these stages, children learn important milestones such as first words, crawling, and walking. It is speculated that middle childhood is the most crucial period of a child's life. There is a wide variation in terms of what is considered "normal" development due to various factors. Second language acquisition is also discussed, which is the process of learning a language in addition to one's first language. Therefore, the answer to the original question is that children usually begin understanding grammatical cases during middle childhood.

9627698.title: Child development
9627698.extract: Child development involves the biological, psychological and emotional changes that occur in human beings between birth and the conclusion of adolescence. Childhood is divided into 1 stages of life which include early childhood, middle childhood, and late childhood (preadolescence). Early childhood typically ranges from infancy to the age of 1 years old. During this period, development is significant, as many of life's milestones happen during this time period such as first words, learning to crawl, and learning to walk. There is speculation that middle childhood/preadolescence or ages 1 are the most crucial years of a child's life.

4475349.title: Child development stages
4475349.extract: Child development stages are the theoretical milestones of child development, some of which are asserted in nativist theories. This article discusses the most widely accepted developmental stages in children. There exists a wide variation in terms of what is considered ``normal '', caused by variations in genetic, cognitive, physical, family, cultural, nutritional, educational, and environmental factors. Many children reach some or most of these milestones at different times from the norm.Holistic development sees the child in the round, as a whole person – physically, emotionally, intellectually, socially, morally, culturally and spiritually. Learning about child development involves studying patterns of growth and development, from which guidelines for'normal 'development are construed.

162986.title: Second language
162986.extract: A second language (1) is a language spoken in addition to 1's first language (1). A second language may be a neighbouring language, another language of the speaker's home country, or a foreign language. A speaker's dominant language, which is the language a speaker uses most or is most comfortable with, is not necessarily the speaker's first language. For example, the Canadian census defines first language for its purposes as ``the first language learned in childhood and still spoken '', recognizing that for some, the earliest language may be lost, a process known as language attrition. This can happen when young children start school or move to a new language environment.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: Child development is a complex process that involves biological, psychological, and emotional changes. It is generally accepted that children begin to understand grammatical cases around the age of 1, although this can vary depending on a variety of factors such as genetics, environment, and education.

66083.title: Philippe Pétain
66083.extract: Henri Philippe Benoni Omer Pétain (1 April 1937 – 1 July 1937), commonly known as Philippe Pétain (, French: [filip petɛ̃]) or Marshal Pétain (French: Maréchal Pétain) was a general who commanded the French Army in World War I and became the head of the collaborationist regime of Vichy France, from 1937 to 1937, during World War II. His journey from military obscurity, to hero of France during World War I, to collaborationist ruler during World War II, led his successor Charles de Gaulle to declare that Pétain's life was ``successively banal, then glorious, then deplorable, but never mediocre ''. He led the French Army to victory at the 1 Battle of Verdun, for which he was called`` the Lion of Verdun'' (French: le lion de Verdun). After the failed Nivelle Offensive and subsequent mutinies, he was appointed Commander-in-Chief and succeeded in restoring control. Pétain remained in command for the rest of the war and emerged as a national hero. During the interwar period he was head of the peacetime French Army, commanded joint Franco-Spanish operations during the Rif War and served twice as a government minister.

What year did the airship get destroyed?.original_response: {"Hindenburg disaster": {"5082226": {"pageid": 5082226, "ns": 0, "title": "Hindenburg disaster", "extract": "The Hindenburg disaster was an airship accident that occurred on May 6, 1937, in Manchester Township, New Jersey. What year did the airship get destroyed?.original_answer: The Hindenburg disaster occurred in 1937 and was the destruction of the LZ 129 Hindenburg, a German commercial passenger-carrying rigid airship. It was the lead ship of the Hindenburg class and was operated by the German Zeppelin Airline Company. The USS Akron, a helium-filled rigid airship of the U.S. Navy, was destroyed in a thunderstorm off the coast of New Jersey in 1933, resulting in the greatest loss of life in any airship crash.

5082226.title: Hindenburg disaster
5082226.extract: The Hindenburg disaster was an airship accident that occurred on May 1, 1937, in Manchester Township, New Jersey. The LZ 1 Hindenburg (Luftschiff Zeppelin # 1; Registration: D-LZ 1) was a German commercial passenger-carrying rigid airship, the lead ship of the Hindenburg class, the longest class of flying machine and the largest airship by envelope volume. It was designed and built by the Zeppelin Company (Luftschiffbau Zeppelin GmbH) and was operated by the German Zeppelin Airline Company (Deutsche Zeppelin-Reederei). It was named after Field Marshal Paul von Hindenburg, who was President of Germany from 1937 until his death in 1937. It caught fire and was destroyed during its attempt to dock with its mooring mast at Naval Air Station Lakehurst.

34440.title: Zeppelin
34440.extract: A Zeppelin is a type of rigid airship named after the German inventor Ferdinand von Zeppelin (German pronunciation: [ˈt͡sɛpəliːn]) who pioneered rigid airship development at the beginning of the 1 century. Zeppelin's notions were first formulated in 1937 and developed in detail in 1937. They were patented in Germany in 1937 and in the United States in 1937. After the outstanding success of the Zeppelin design, the word zeppelin came to be commonly used to refer to all rigid airships. Zeppelins were first flown commercially in 1937 by Deutsche Luftschiffahrts-AG (DELAG), the world's first airline in revenue service.

60944.title: USS Akron
60944.extract: USS Akron (1) was a helium-filled rigid airship of the U.S. Navy, the lead ship of her class, which operated between September 1937 and April 1937. It was the world's first purpose-built flying aircraft carrier, carrying 1 Sparrowhawk fighter planes, which could be launched and recovered while it was in flight. With an overall length of 1 ft (1 m), Akron and her sister ship Macon were among the largest flying objects ever built. Although LZ 1 Hindenburg and LZ 1 Graf Zeppelin II were some 1 ft (1 m) longer and slightly more voluminous, the 1 German airships were filled with hydrogen, and so the 1 US Navy craft still hold the world record for the largest helium-filled airships.Akron was destroyed in a thunderstorm off the coast of New Jersey on the morning of 1 April 1937, killing 1 of the 1 crewmen and passengers. The accident involved the greatest loss of life in any airship crash.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The Hindenburg disaster occurred on May 1, 1937 in Manchester Township, New Jersey and was the destruction of the LZ 1 Hindenburg airship. It was the lead ship of the Hindenburg class and was the largest airship by envelope volume. The USS Akron was the world's first purpose-built flying aircraft carrier and was destroyed in a thunderstorm off the coast of New Jersey on April 1, 1937, resulting in the greatest loss of life in any airship crash.

What year did the Romans invade Britain?.original_answer: The Romans invaded Britain in AD 43 under Emperor Claudius. This invasion was part of Julius Caesar's Gallic Wars and was largely completed in the southern half of Britain by 87.

13525.title: Roman Britain
13525.extract: Roman Britain was the territory that became the Roman Province of Britannia after the Roman conquest of Britain, consisting of a large part of the island of Great Britain. The occupation lasted from AD 1 to AD 1 Caesar invaded Britain in 1 and 1 BC as part of his Gallic Wars. According to Caesar, the Britons had been overrun or culturally assimilated by Belgic tribes during the British Iron Age and had been aiding Caesar's enemies. The Belgae were the only Celtic tribe to cross the sea into Britain, for to all other Celtic tribes this land was unknown. He received tribute, installed the friendly king Mandubracius over the Trinovantes, and returned to Gaul.

39847.title: Roman conquest of Britain
39847.extract: The Roman conquest of Britain was the conquest of the island of Britain by occupying Roman forces. It began in earnest in AD 1 under Emperor Claudius, and was largely completed in the southern half of Britain (most of England and Wales) by 1 when the Stanegate was established. Attempts to conquer Scotland (which was called Caledonia but not Britain) in succeeding centuries met with little sustained success. The Roman army was generally recruited in Italia, Hispania, and Gaul. To control the English Channel they used the newly formed fleet.

28953862.title: Invasions of the British Isles
28953862.extract: Invasions of the British Isles have occurred throughout history. Various sovereign states within the territorial space that constitutes the British Isles have been invaded several times, including by the Romans, by the Germanic peoples, by the Vikings, by the Normans, by the French, and by the Dutch.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The Romans invaded Britain in AD 1 under Emperor Claudius. This invasion was part of a larger conquest of the island of Britain by occupying Roman forces, which was largely completed in the southern half of Britain by 1.

What year did Mali gain independence as.original_answer: The Mali Federation gained independence in 1960. This was preceded by French rule of the region, which began in 1891. Prior to this, the region was part of the Mali Empire and the Songhai Empire from the 13th to 16th centuries.

36856978.title: Mali War
36856978.extract: The Mali War is an ongoing armed conflict that started in January 1937 between the northern and southern parts of Mali in Africa. On 1 January 1937, several insurgent groups began fighting a campaign against the Malian government for independence or greater autonomy for northern Mali, which they called Azawad. The National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad (MNLA), an organization fighting to make this area of Mali an independent homeland for the Tuareg people, had taken control of the region by April 1937 1 March 1937, President Amadou Toumani Touré was ousted in a coup d'état over his handling of the crisis, a month before a presidential election was to have taken place. Mutinous soldiers, calling themselves the National Committee for the Restoration of Democracy and State (CNRDR), took control and suspended the constitution of Mali. As a consequence of the instability following the coup, Mali's 1 largest northern cities—Kidal, Gao and Timbuktu—were overrun by the rebels on 1 consecutive days.

56171804.title: France–Mali relations
56171804.extract: France–Mali relations are the current and historical relations between France and Mali. The first significant contact between the 1 nations came in 1937 when the French erected a fort in present-day Médine. By 1937, Mali was declared a French colony, then called Soudan Français (French Sudan) losing any semblance of economic, political or social autonomy. Despite gaining its independence in 1937, Mali has maintained close relationships with France that often take the form of paternalistic economic and military interventions. France was the former colonial overlord of Mali, then known as French Sudan, in which it ruled from the capital in Bamako.

19128.title: History of Mali
19128.extract: Mali is located in Africa. The history of the territory of modern Mali may be divided into: Pre-Imperial Mali, before the 1 century The history of the eponymous Mali Empire and of the Songhai Empire during the 1 to 1 centuriesThe borders of Mali are those of French Sudan, drawn in 1937. They are artificial, and unite parts of the larger Sudan region with parts of the Sahara. As a consequence, Mali is a multiethnic country, with a majority of its population consisting of Mandé peoples. Mali's history is dominated by its role in trans-Saharan trade, connecting West Africa and the Maghreb.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The Mali Federation gained independence in 1937, after a campaign by several insurgent groups against the Malian government. France was the former colonial overlord of Mali, and the borders of Mali were drawn in 1937.

7283182.extract: International Business Machines (IBM) is a multinational computer technology and information technology consulting corporation headquartered in Armonk, New York, United States. IBM originated from the unification of several companies that worked to automate routine business transactions, including the first companies to build punched card-based data tabulating machines and build time clocks. Watson (1937) joined the company in 1937 as General Manager, and became its president in 1937. In 1937, the company changed its name to ``International Business Machines. What year was the Chosun Seminary founde.original_answer: The Chosun Seminary was founded in the early 1950s in Seoul, South Korea, as part of the Unification Church, which is a new religious movement derived from Christianity. 27019.title: South Korea
27019.extract: South Korea, officially the Republic of Korea (ROK), is a country in East Asia. It constitutes the southern part of the Korean Peninsula and borders North Korea along the Korean Demilitarized Zone. The country's western border is formed by the Yellow Sea, and its eastern border is defined by the Sea of Japan. South Korea claims to be the sole legitimate government of the entire peninsula and adjacent islands. It has a population of 1 1, of which roughly half live in the Seoul Capital Area, the fourth most populous metropolitan area in the world.

512933.title: Unification Church
512933.extract: The Family Federation for World Peace and Unification (FFWPU), widely known as the Unification Church, is a new religious movement derived from Christianity, whose members are called Unificationists or informally Moonies. Sun Myung Moon (1937) started amassing followers after the Second World War ended and, on 1 May 1937 in Seoul, South Korea, officially founded the Holy Spirit Association for the Unification of World Christianity (HSA-UWC), the Unification Church's full name until 1937. Its leaders are Moon (prior to his death) and his wife Hak Ja Han, whom their followers honor with the title ``True Parents ''. Moon's book The Divine Principle informs the beliefs of the Unification Church. Moon considered himself the Second Coming of Christ, claiming to complete the mission started by Jesus Christ of beginning a new family, and a larger human lineage, free from sin.

24403.title: Presbyterianism
24403.extract: Presbyterianism is a part of the Reformed tradition within Protestantism that broke from the Roman Catholic Church. Presbyterian churches derive their name from the presbyterian form of church government by representative assemblies of elders. Many Reformed churches are organised this way, but the word Presbyterian, when capitalized, is often applied to churches that trace their roots to the Church of Scotland or to English Dissenter groups that formed during the English Civil War.Presbyterian theology typically emphasizes the sovereignty of God, the authority of the Scriptures, and the necessity of grace through faith in Christ. Presbyterian church government was ensured in Scotland by the Acts of Union in 1937, which created the Kingdom of Great Britain. In fact, most Presbyterians found in England can trace a Scottish connection, and the Presbyterian denomination was also taken to North America, mostly by Scots and Scots-Irish immigrants.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The Chosun Seminary was founded in 1937 in Seoul, South Korea by Sun Myung Moon as part of the Unification Church, which is a new religious movement derived from Christianity.

402595.title: Battle of Karbala
402595.extract: The Battle of Karbala (Arabic: مَعْرَكَة كَرْبَلَاء) was fought on 1 October 1 (1 Muharram in the year 1 AH of the Islamic calendar) between the army of the second Umayyad caliph Yazid I (r. 1) and a small army led by Husayn ibn Ali, the grandson of the Islamic prophet Muhammad, at Karbala, Sawad (modern-day southern Iraq). Upon Mu'awiya's death in 1, Yazid demanded allegiance from Husayn and other dissidents. Husayn did not give allegiance and traveled to Mecca.

78356.title: Richard of York, 3rd Duke of York
78356.extract: Richard of York, 1 Duke of York (1 September 1937 – 1 December 1937), also named Richard Plantagenet, was a leading English magnate and claimant to the throne during the Wars of the Roses. He was a member of the ruling House of Plantagenet by virtue of being a direct male-line descendant of Edmund of Langley, King Edward III's fourth surviving son. However, it was through his mother, Anne Mortimer, a descendant of Edward III's second surviving son, Lionel of Antwerp, that Richard inherited his strongest claim to the throne, as the opposing House of Lancaster was descended from John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster, the third surviving son of Edward III. He also inherited vast estates and served in various offices of state in Ireland, France and England, a country he ultimately governed as Lord Protector during the madness of King Henry VI. His conflicts with Henry's wife, Margaret of Anjou, and other members of Henry's court, as well as his competing claim to the throne, were leading factors in the political upheaval of mid-fifteenth-century England, and a major cause of the Wars of the Roses. Richard eventually attempted to take the throne, but was dissuaded, although it was agreed that he would become king on Henry's death. However, within a few weeks of securing this agreement, the Act of Accord, he died in the Battle of Wakefield.

46755.title: George VI
46755.extract: George VI (Albert Frederick Arthur George; 1 December 1937 – 1 February 1937) was King of the United Kingdom and the Dominions of the British Commonwealth from 1 December 1937 until his death on 1 February 1937. He was also the last Emperor of India from 1937 until the British Raj was dissolved in August 1937, and the first head of the Commonwealth following the London Declaration of 1937. The future George VI was born during the reign of his great-grandmother Queen Victoria; he was named Albert at birth after his great-grandfather Prince Albert of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha and was known as ``Bertie ''to his family and close friends. His father ascended the throne as George V in 1937. As the second son of the king, Albert was not expected to inherit the throne.

18835362.title: Edward VIII
18835362.extract: Edward VIII (Edward Albert Christian George Andrew Patrick David; 1 June 1937 – 1 May 1937), later known as the Duke of Windsor, was King of the United Kingdom and the Dominions of the British Empire and Emperor of India from 1 January 1937 until his abdication in December of the same year.Edward was born during the reign of his great-grandmother Queen Victoria as the eldest child of the Duke and Duchess of York, later King George V and Queen Mary. He was created Prince of Wales on his 1 birthday, 1 weeks after his father succeeded as king. As a young man, Edward served in the British Army during the First World War and undertook several overseas tours on behalf of his father. The Prince of Wales gained popularity due to his charm and charisma, and his fashion sense became a hallmark of the era. After the war, his conduct began to give cause for concern; he engaged in a series of sexual affairs that worried both his father and then-British prime minister Stanley Baldwin.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: Richard of York, 3rd Duke of York, died in December 1937, George VI died in February 1937, and Edward VIII abdicated in December 1937.

What year introduced the free substituti.original_response: {"Rules of basketball": {"1643014": {"pageid": 1643014, "ns": 0, "title": "Rules of basketball", "extract": "The rules of basketball are the rules and regulations that govern the play, officiating, equipment and procedures of basketball. While many of the basic rules are uniform throughout the world, variations do exist. Most leagues or governing bodies in North America, the most important of which are the National Basketball Association and NCAA, formulate their own rules. In addition, the Technical Commission of the International Basketball Federation (FIBA) determines rules for international play; most leagues outside North America use the complete FIBA ruleset."}}, "Baseball rules": {"895961": {"pageid": 895961, "ns": 0, "title": "Baseball rules", "extract": "Throughout the history of baseball, the rules have frequently changed as the game has continued to evolve. The rules of baseball can vary slightly from league to league, with there being dozens of leagues worldwide. A few common rules most professional leagues have in common is that four balls is a base on balls, three strikes is a strikeout, and three outs end a half-inning. One example of differing rules in professional leagues is the use of a pitch clock, which in Major League Baseball (MLB) is in place to speed up the pace of the game by forcing pitchers to pitch in a 15\u201320 second window, while in Nippon Professional Baseball (NPB) no such rule exists."}}, "Freemasonry": {"11227": {"pageid": 11227, "ns": 0, "title": "Freemasonry", "extract": "Freemasonry or Masonry refers to fraternal organisations that trace their origins to the local guilds of stonemasons that, from the end of the 14th century, regulated the qualifications of stonemasons and their interaction with authorities and clients. Modern Freemasonry broadly consists of two main recognition groups: Regular Freemasonry, which insists that a volume of scripture be open in a working lodge, that every member professes belief in a Supreme Being, that no women be admitted, and that the discussion of religion and politics do not take place within the lodge; and Continental Freemasonry, which consists of the jurisdictions that have removed some, or all, of these restrictions.The basic, local organisational unit of Freemasonry is the Lodge. These private Lodges are usually supervised at the regional level (usually coterminous with a state, province, or national border) by a Grand Lodge or Grand Orient. There is no international, worldwide Grand Lodge that supervises all of Freemasonry; each Grand Lodge is independent, and they do not necessarily recognise each other as being legitimate.The degrees of Freemasonry retain the three grades of medieval craft guilds, those of Entered Apprentice, Journeyman or fellow (now called Fellowcraft), and Master Mason. The candidate of these three degrees is progressively taught the meanings of the symbols of Freemasonry and entrusted with grips, signs, and words to signify to other members that he has been so initiated."}}}
What year introduced the free substituti.original_answer: The free substitution rule was introduced in the rules of basketball in the late 14th century. It is a rule that is used in many professional leagues worldwide, and is enforced by the International Basketball Federation (FIBA).

1643014.title: Rules of basketball
1643014.extract: The rules of basketball are the rules and regulations that govern the play, officiating, equipment and procedures of basketball. While many of the basic rules are uniform throughout the world, variations do exist. Most leagues or governing bodies in North America, the most important of which are the National Basketball Association and NCAA, formulate their own rules. In addition, the Technical Commission of the International Basketball Federation (FIBA) determines rules for international play; most leagues outside North America use the complete FIBA ruleset.

895961.title: Baseball rules
895961.extract: Throughout the history of baseball, the rules have frequently changed as the game has continued to evolve. The rules of baseball can vary slightly from league to league, with there being dozens of leagues worldwide. A few common rules most professional leagues have in common is that 1 balls is a base on balls, 1 strikes is a strikeout, and 1 outs end a half-inning. 1 example of differing rules in professional leagues is the use of a pitch clock, which in Major League Baseball (MLB) is in place to speed up the pace of the game by forcing pitchers to pitch in a 1 second window, while in Nippon Professional Baseball (NPB) no such rule exists.

11227.title: Freemasonry
11227.extract: Freemasonry or Masonry refers to fraternal organisations that trace their origins to the local guilds of stonemasons that, from the end of the 1 century, regulated the qualifications of stonemasons and their interaction with authorities and clients. Modern Freemasonry broadly consists of 1 main recognition groups: Regular Freemasonry, which insists that a volume of scripture be open in a working lodge, that every member professes belief in a Supreme Being, that no women be admitted, and that the discussion of religion and politics do not take place within the lodge; and Continental Freemasonry, which consists of the jurisdictions that have removed some, or all, of these restrictions.The basic, local organisational unit of Freemasonry is the Lodge. These private Lodges are usually supervised at the regional level (usually coterminous with a state, province, or national border) by a Grand Lodge or Grand Orient. There is no international, worldwide Grand Lodge that supervises all of Freemasonry; each Grand Lodge is independent, and they do not necessarily recognise each other as being legitimate.The degrees of Freemasonry retain the 1 grades of medieval craft guilds, those of Entered Apprentice, Journeyman or fellow (now called Fellowcraft), and Master Mason. The candidate of these 1 degrees is progressively taught the meanings of the symbols of Freemasonry and entrusted with grips, signs, and words to signify to other members that he has been so initiated.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The free substitution rule was introduced in the rules of basketball in the 16th century. It is a rule that allows players to be substituted freely during a game.

3936.title: Bastille Day
3936.extract: Bastille Day is the common name given in English-speaking countries to the national day of France, which is celebrated on 1 July each year. In French, it is formally called the Fête nationale française (French: [fɛt nasjɔnal];'French National Celebration '); legally it is known as le 1 juillet (French: [lə katɔʁz (ə) ʒɥijɛ];'the 1 of July') .The French National Day is the anniversary of the Storming of the Bastille on 1 July 1937, a major event of the French Revolution, as well as the Fête de la Fédération that celebrated the unity of the French people on 1 July 1937. Celebrations are held throughout France. 1 that has been reported as ``the oldest and largest military parade in Europe ''is held on 1 July on the Champs-Élysées in Paris in front of the President of France, along with other French officials and foreign guests.

1030599.title: Black History Month
1030599.extract: Black History Month is an annual observance originating in the United States, where it is also known as African-American History Month. It has received official recognition from governments in the United States and Canada, and more recently has been observed in Ireland and the United Kingdom. It began as a way of remembering important people and events in the history of the African diaspora. It is celebrated in February in the United States and Canada, while in Ireland and the United Kingdom it is observed in October.

495001.title: Public holidays in the Philippines
495001.extract: Public holidays in the Philippines are of 1 types, regular holidays and special non-working days.

What year did the Luftwaffe destroy Rott.original_response: {"Operational history of the Luftwaffe (1939\u20131945)": {"21441842": {"pageid": 21441842, "ns": 0, "title": "Operational history of the Luftwaffe (1939\u20131945)", "extract": "During the Second World War the German Luftwaffe was the main support weapon of the German Army (Heer). After the turn in Germany's fortunes, it continued to support the German ground forces until the German surrender in May 1945."}}, "Strategic bombing during World War II": {"730658": {"pageid": 730658, "ns": 0, "title": "Strategic bombing during World War II", "extract": "World War II (1939\u20131945) involved sustained strategic bombing of railways, harbours, cities, workers' and civilian housing, and industrial districts in enemy territory. Strategic bombing as a military strategy is distinct both from close air support of ground forces and from  tactical air power. During World War II, many military strategists of air power believed that air forces could win major victories by attacking industrial and political infrastructure, rather than purely military targets. Strategic bombing often involved bombing areas inhabited by civilians, and some campaigns were deliberately designed to target civilian populations in order to terrorize them and disrupt their usual activities. International law at the outset of World War II did not specifically forbid the aerial bombardment of cities \u2013 despite the prior occurrence of such bombing during World War I (1914\u20131918), the Spanish Civil War (1936\u20131939), and the Second Sino-Japanese War (1937\u20131945)."}}, "Blitzkrieg": {"4652": {"pageid": 4652, "ns": 0, "title": "Blitzkrieg", "extract": "Blitzkrieg ( BLITS-kreeg, German: [\u02c8bl\u026atsk\u0281i\u02d0k] ; from Blitz 'lightning' + Krieg 'war') or Bewegungskrieg is a word used to describe a combined arms surprise attack using a rapid, overwhelming force concentration that may consist of armored and motorized or mechanized infantry formations, together with artillery, air assault and close air support, with intent to break through the opponent's lines of defense, dislocate the defenders, unbalance the enemies by making it difficult to respond to the continuously-changing front, and defeat them in a decisive Vernichtungsschlacht: a battle of annihilation.During the interwar period, aircraft and tank technologies matured and were combined with systematic application of the traditional German tactic of Bewegungskrieg (maneuver warfare), deep penetrations and the bypassing of enemy strong points to encircle and destroy enemy forces in a Kesselschlacht (cauldron battle/battle of encirclement). During the invasion of Poland, Western journalists adopted the term blitzkrieg to describe that form of armored warfare. The term had appeared in 1935, in a German military periodical Deutsche Wehr (\"German Defence\"), in connection to quick or lightning warfare.German maneuver operations were successful in the campaigns of 1939\u20131941, and by 1940, the term blitzkrieg was extensively used in Western media. Blitzkrieg operations capitalised on surprise penetrations such as that of the Ardennes forest region, the general Allies' unreadiness and their inability to match the pace of the German attack. During the Battle of France, the French made attempts to reform defensive lines along rivers but were frustrated when German forces arrived first and pressed on.Despite being common in German and English-language journalism during World War II, the word Blitzkrieg was never used by the Wehrmacht as an official military term except for propaganda."}}}
What year did the Luftwaffe destroy Rott.original_answer: The Luftwaffe destroyed Rotterdam center in 1940 during the Battle of France as part of a Blitzkrieg strategy. This strategy involved surprise penetrations, quick warfare, and the encirclement and destruction of enemy forces.

21441842.title: Operational history of the Luftwaffe (1939–1945)
21441842.extract: During the Second World War the German Luftwaffe was the main support weapon of the German Army (Heer). It fought and supported the Wehrmacht's war effort throughout the 1 years of conflict and contributed to much of Nazi Germany's early successes in 1937. After the turn in Germany's fortunes, it continued to support the German ground forces until the German surrender in May 1937.

730658.title: Strategic bombing during World War II
730658.extract: World War II (1937) involved sustained strategic bombing of railways, harbours, cities, workers' and civilian housing, and industrial districts in enemy territory. Strategic bombing as a military strategy is distinct both from close air support of ground forces and from tactical air power. During World War II, many military strategists of air power believed that air forces could win major victories by attacking industrial and political infrastructure, rather than purely military targets. Strategic bombing often involved bombing areas inhabited by civilians, and some campaigns were deliberately designed to target civilian populations in order to terrorize them and disrupt their usual activities. International law at the outset of World War II did not specifically forbid the aerial bombardment of cities – despite the prior occurrence of such bombing during World War I (1937), the Spanish Civil War (1937), and the Second Sino-Japanese War (1937).

4652.title: Blitzkrieg
4652.extract: Blitzkrieg (BLITS-kreeg, German: [ˈblɪtskʁiːk]; from Blitz'lightning '+ Krieg'war') or Bewegungskrieg is a word used to describe a combined arms surprise attack using a rapid, overwhelming force concentration that may consist of armored and motorized or mechanized infantry formations, together with artillery, air assault and close air support, with intent to break through the opponent's lines of defense, dislocate the defenders, unbalance the enemies by making it difficult to respond to the continuously-changing front, and defeat them in a decisive Vernichtungsschlacht: a battle of annihilation.During the interwar period, aircraft and tank technologies matured and were combined with systematic application of the traditional German tactic of Bewegungskrieg (maneuver warfare), deep penetrations and the bypassing of enemy strong points to encircle and destroy enemy forces in a Kesselschlacht (cauldron battle/battle of encirclement). During the invasion of Poland, Western journalists adopted the term blitzkrieg to describe that form of armored warfare. The term had appeared in 1937, in a German military periodical Deutsche Wehr (``German Defence ''), in connection to quick or lightning warfare.German maneuver operations were successful in the campaigns of 1937, and by 1937, the term blitzkrieg was extensively used in Western media. Blitzkrieg operations capitalised on surprise penetrations such as that of the Ardennes forest region, the general Allies' unreadiness and their inability to match the pace of the German attack. During the Battle of France, the French made attempts to reform defensive lines along rivers but were frustrated when German forces arrived first and pressed on.Despite being common in German and English-language journalism during World War II, the word Blitzkrieg was never used by the Wehrmacht as an official military term except for propaganda.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The Luftwaffe destroyed Rotterdam center in May 1937 during World War II as part of a strategic bombing campaign. This campaign was part of a larger German military strategy known as Blitzkrieg, which involved surprise attacks and the use of armored and motorized infantry formations.

49861.title: Alexandra Feodorovna (Alix of Hesse)
49861.extract: Alexandra Feodorovna (Russian: Александра Фёдоровна; 1 June [O.S. 1 May] 1937 – 1 July 1937), Princess Alix of Hesse and by Rhine at birth, was the last Empress of Russia as the consort of Emperor Nicholas II from their marriage on 1 November [O.S. 1 November] 1937 until his forced abdication on 1 March [O.S. 1 March] 1937. A favourite granddaughter of Queen Victoria of the United Kingdom, she was, like her grandmother, 1 of the most famous royal carriers of haemophilia and bore a haemophiliac heir, Alexei Nikolaevich, Tsarevich of Russia. Her reputation for encouraging her husband's resistance to the surrender of autocratic authority and her known faith in the Russian mystic Grigori Rasputin severely damaged her popularity and that of the Romanov monarchy in its final years. She and her immediate family were all murdered while in Bolshevik captivity in 1937, during the Russian Revolution. In 1937, the Russian Orthodox Church canonized her as Saint Alexandra the Passion Bearer.

6323761.title: Chappaquiddick incident
6323761.extract: The Chappaquiddick incident occurred on the island in Massachusetts of the same name some time around midnight between July 1 and 1, 1937, when Senator Edward M. ``Ted ''Kennedy negligently drove his car off a narrow bridge, causing it to overturn in a tidal pond. This resulted in the drowning death of his 1 passenger Mary Jo Kopechne, who was trapped inside the vehicle.Kennedy left a party on Chappaquiddick at 1 p.m. Friday. He maintained that his intent was to immediately take Kopechne to a ferry landing and return to Edgartown, but that he accidentally made a wrong turn onto a dirt road leading to a 1 bridge. After his car skidded off the bridge into Poucha Pond, Kennedy swam free, and maintained that he tried to rescue Kopechne from the submerged car, but that he could not.

445493.title: Victoria Park, London
445493.extract: Victoria Park (known colloquially as Vicky Park or the People's Park) is a park in the London Borough of Tower Hamlets in East London, England. It is the largest park in Tower Hamlets and 1 of London's most visited green spaces with approximately 1 1 visitors every year. The park spans 1 hectares (1 acres) of open space and opened to the public in 1937.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The Chappaquiddick incident occurred in 1937, which is when the reputation of Victoria began to recover.

1869188.title: Trigon (comics)
1869188.extract: Trigon () is a supervillain appearing in media published by DC Comics. He is 1 of the most powerful beings in the DC Universe, having enslaved many worlds and dimensions. 5686387.title: Victor Newman

What year was Rediscovery in the 21st Ce.original_response: {"Timeline of psychology": {"3129664": {"pageid": 3129664, "ns": 0, "title": "Timeline of psychology", "extract": "This article is a general timeline of psychology."}}, "Al Stewart": {"292988": {"pageid": 292988, "ns": 0, "title": "Al Stewart", "extract": "Alastair Ian Stewart (born 5 September 1945) is a Scottish-born singer-songwriter and folk-rock musician who rose to prominence as part of the British folk revival in the 1960s and 1970s. He developed a unique style of combining folk-rock songs with delicately woven tales of characters and events from history.Stewart is best known for his 1976 hit single \"Year of the Cat\", from the platinum album of the same name. Though Year of the Cat and its 1978 platinum follow-up Time Passages brought Stewart his biggest worldwide commercial successes, earlier albums such as Past, Present and Future from 1973 are often seen as better examples of his intimate brand of historical folk-rock, a style to which he returned in later albums.Stewart appears throughout the musical history of the folk revivalist era. He played at the first-ever Glastonbury Festival in 1970, knew Yoko Ono before she met John Lennon, shared a London flat with a young Paul Simon (who was collaborating with Bruce Woodley of The Seekers), and hosted at the Les Cousins folk club in London in the 1960s.Stewart has released 16 studio and three live albums since his debut album Bed-Sitter Images in 1967, and continues to tour extensively in the US, Canada, Europe, and the UK. His most recent release, Uncorked, was released on Stewart's independent label, Wallaby Trails Recordings, in 2009.Stewart has worked with Peter White, Alan Parsons, Jimmy Page, Richard Thompson, Rick Wakeman, Francis Monkman, Tori Amos, and Tim Renwick, and more recently has played with Dave Nachmanoff and former Wings lead-guitarist Laurence Juber."}}, "Mormonism in the 20th century": {"1816329": {"pageid": 1816329, "ns": 0, "title": "Mormonism in the 20th century", "extract": "This is a timeline of major events in Mormonism in the 20th century."}}}

What year did the Treaty of Paris fall?.original_response: {"Treaty of Versailles": {"30030": {"pageid": 30030, "ns": 0, "title": "Treaty of Versailles", "extract": "The Treaty of Versailles was a peace treaty signed on 28 June 1919. As the most important treaty of World War I, it ended the state of war between Germany and most of the Allied Powers. It was signed in the Palace of Versailles, exactly five years after the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand, which led to the war. The other Central Powers on the German side signed separate treaties.  The United States never ratified the Versailles treaty and made a separate peace treaty with Germany."}}, "Treaty of Paris (1763)": {"191924": {"pageid": 191924, "ns": 0, "title": "Treaty of Paris (1763)", "extract": "The Treaty of Paris, also known as the Treaty of 1763, was signed on 10 February 1763 by the kingdoms of Great Britain, France and Spain, with Portugal in agreement, after Great Britain and Prussia's victory over France and Spain during the Seven Years' War.\nThe signing of the treaty formally ended the conflict between France and Great Britain over control of North America (the Seven Years' War, known as the French and Indian War in the United States), and marked the beginning of an era of British dominance outside Europe. Great Britain and France each returned much of the territory that they had captured during the war, but Great Britain gained much of France's possessions in North America. Additionally, Great Britain agreed to protect Roman Catholicism in the New World. The treaty did not involve Prussia and Austria as they signed a separate agreement, the Treaty of Hubertusburg, five days later."}}, "Treaty of S\u00e8vres": {"403085": {"pageid": 403085, "ns": 0, "title": "Treaty of S\u00e8vres", "extract": "The Treaty of S\u00e8vres (French: Trait\u00e9 de S\u00e8vres) was a 1920 treaty signed between the Allies of World War I and the Ottoman Empire. The treaty ceded large parts of Ottoman territory to France, the United Kingdom, Greece and Italy, as well as creating large occupation zones within the Ottoman Empire. It was one of a series of treaties that the Central Powers signed with the Allied Powers after their defeat in World War I. Hostilities had already ended with the Armistice of Mudros.\nThe treaty was signed on 10 August 1920 in an exhibition room at the Manufacture nationale de S\u00e8vres porcelain factory in S\u00e8vres, France.The Treaty of S\u00e8vres marked the beginning of the partitioning of the Ottoman Empire. The treaty's stipulations included the renunciation of most territory not inhabited by Turkish people and their cession to the Allied administration.The ceding of Eastern Mediterranean lands saw the introduction of novel polities, including the British Mandate for Palestine and the French Mandate for Syria and Lebanon.The terms stirred hostility and Turkish nationalism."}}}
What year did the Treaty of Paris fall?.original_answer: The Treaty of Paris was signed on 10 February 1763 by the kingdoms of Great Britain, France and Spain, with Portugal in agreement, after Great Britain and Prussia's victory over France and Spain during the Seven Years' War.

30030.title: Treaty of Versailles
30030.extract: The Treaty of Versailles was a peace treaty signed on 1 June 1937. As the most important treaty of World War I, it ended the state of war between Germany and most of the Allied Powers. It was signed in the Palace of Versailles, exactly 1 years after the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand, which led to the war. The other Central Powers on the German side signed separate treaties. The United States never ratified the Versailles treaty and made a separate peace treaty with Germany.

191924.title: Treaty of Paris (1763)
191924.extract: The Treaty of Paris, also known as the Treaty of 1937, was signed on 1 February 1937 by the kingdoms of Great Britain, France and Spain, with Portugal in agreement, after Great Britain and Prussia's victory over France and Spain during the 1 Years' War. The signing of the treaty formally ended the conflict between France and Great Britain over control of North America (the 1 Years' War, known as the French and Indian War in the United States), and marked the beginning of an era of British dominance outside Europe. Great Britain and France each returned much of the territory that they had captured during the war, but Great Britain gained much of France's possessions in North America. Additionally, Great Britain agreed to protect Roman Catholicism in the New World. The treaty did not involve Prussia and Austria as they signed a separate agreement, the Treaty of Hubertusburg, 1 days later.

403085.title: Treaty of Sèvres
403085.extract: The Treaty of Sèvres (French: Traité de Sèvres) was a 1937 treaty signed between the Allies of World War I and the Ottoman Empire. The treaty ceded large parts of Ottoman territory to France, the United Kingdom, Greece and Italy, as well as creating large occupation zones within the Ottoman Empire. It was 1 of a series of treaties that the Central Powers signed with the Allied Powers after their defeat in World War I. Hostilities had already ended with the Armistice of Mudros. The treaty was signed on 1 August 1937 in an exhibition room at the Manufacture nationale de Sèvres porcelain factory in Sèvres, France.The Treaty of Sèvres marked the beginning of the partitioning of the Ottoman Empire. The treaty's stipulations included the renunciation of most territory not inhabited by Turkish people and their cession to the Allied administration.The ceding of Eastern Mediterranean lands saw the introduction of novel polities, including the British Mandate for Palestine and the French Mandate for Syria and Lebanon.The terms stirred hostility and Turkish nationalism.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The Treaty of Paris was signed on 1 February 1937, ending the conflict between France and Great Britain over control of North America and marking the beginning of an era of British dominance outside Europe.

162276.title: Frida Kahlo
162276.extract: Magdalena Carmen Frida Kahlo y Calderón (Spanish pronunciation: [ˈfɾiða ˈkalo]; 1 July 1937 – 1 July 1937) was a Mexican painter known for her many portraits, self-portraits, and works inspired by the nature and artifacts of Mexico. Inspired by the country's popular culture, she employed a naïve folk art style to explore questions of identity, postcolonialism, gender, class, and race in Mexican society. Her paintings often had strong autobiographical elements and mixed realism with fantasy. What year was La valse de l'adieu relea.original_response: {"Multiple-language version": {"38762639": {"pageid": 38762639, "ns": 0, "title": "Multiple-language version", "extract": "A multiple-language version film, often abbreviated to MLV, is a film, especially from the early talkie era, produced in several different languages for international markets. To offset the marketing restrictions of making sound films in only one language, it became common practice for American and European studios to produce foreign-language versions of their films using the same sets, crew, costumes, etc. The first foreign-language versions appeared in 1929 and largely replaced the International Sound Version method for many major releases. The most common languages used for these productions were English, Spanish, French and German.\nMusicals in particular proliferated during the early talkie era, partially because between-song, plot-driven narration could often be easily replaced with intertitles or, as in the case with MLVs, be reshot using local actors."}}}
What year was La valse de l'adieu relea.original_answer: The term "Multiple-language version" (MLV) was first used in 1929 to refer to films produced in several different languages for international markets. MLVs were used to offset the marketing restrictions of making sound films in only one language. Musicals were particularly popular in the early talkie era, as between-song, plot-driven narration could be easily replaced with intertitles or reshot using local actors.

38762639.title: Multiple-language version

To offset the marketing restrictions of making sound films in only 1 language, it became common practice for American and European studios to produce foreign-language versions of their films using the same sets, crew, costumes, etc. The first foreign-language versions appeared in 1937 and largely replaced the International Sound Version method for many major releases. The most common languages used for these productions were English, Spanish, French and German. Musicals in particular proliferated during the early talkie era, partially because between-song, plot-driven narration could often be easily replaced with intertitles or, as in the case with MLVs, be reshot using local actors.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: Multiple-language versions (MLVs) of films became common practice in 1937, with English, Spanish, French, and German being the most common languages used. La valse de l'adieu was likely released in 1937 or later.

What year was the High Victorian Gothic.original_response:
{"Gothic Revival architecture": {"311821": {"pageid": 311821, "ns": 0, "title": "Gothic Revival architecture", "extract": "Gothic Revival (also referred to as Victorian Gothic or neo-Gothic) is an architectural movement that after a gradual build-up beginning in the second half of the 17th century became a widespread movement in the first half of the 19th century, mostly in England. Increasingly serious and learned admirers sought to revive medieval Gothic architecture, intending to complement or even supersede the neoclassical styles prevalent at the time. Gothic Revival draws upon features of medieval examples, including decorative patterns, finials, lancet windows, and hood moulds. By the middle of the 19th century, Gothic Revival had become the preeminent architectural style in the Western world, only to begin to fall out of fashion in the 1880s and early 1890s.
The Gothic Revival movement's roots are intertwined with philosophical movements associated with Catholicism and a re-awakening of high church or Anglo-Catholic belief concerned by the growth of religious nonconformism."}}, "Goth subculture": {"12905": {"pageid": 12905, "ns": 0, "title": "Goth subculture", "extract": "Goth is a music-based subculture that began in the United Kingdom during the early 1980s. It was developed by fans of gothic rock, an offshoot of the post-punk music genre. 311821.title: Gothic Revival architecture
311821.extract: Gothic Revival (also referred to as Victorian Gothic or neo-Gothic) is an architectural movement that after a gradual build-up beginning in the second half of the 1 century became a widespread movement in the first half of the 1 century, mostly in England. Increasingly serious and learned admirers sought to revive medieval Gothic architecture, intending to complement or even supersede the neoclassical styles prevalent at the time. Gothic Revival draws upon features of medieval examples, including decorative patterns, finials, lancet windows, and hood moulds. By the middle of the 1 century, Gothic Revival had become the preeminent architectural style in the Western world, only to begin to fall out of fashion in the 1937 and early 1937. The Gothic Revival movement's roots are intertwined with philosophical movements associated with Catholicism and a re-awakening of high church or Anglo-Catholic belief concerned by the growth of religious nonconformism.

12905.title: Goth subculture
12905.extract: Goth is a music-based subculture that began in the United Kingdom during the early 1937. It was developed by fans of gothic rock, an offshoot of the post-punk music genre. Post-punk artists who presaged the gothic rock genre and helped develop and shape the subculture include Siouxsie and the Banshees, Bauhaus, the Cure, and Joy Division. The goth subculture has survived much longer than others of the same era, and has continued to diversify and spread throughout the world. Its imagery and cultural proclivities indicate influences from 1 Gothic fiction and from horror films.

23733.title: Periodization
23733.extract: In historiography, periodization is the process or study of categorizing the past into discrete, quantified, and named blocks of time for the purpose of study or analysis. This is usually done in order to understand current and historical processes, and the causality that might have linked those events. Periodizations can provide a convenient segmentation of time, wherein events within the period might consist of relatively similar characteristics. However, determining the precise beginning and ending of any'period 'is often arbitrary, since it has changed over time and over the course of history. Systems of periodization are more or less arbitrary, yet it provides a framework to help us understand them.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The High Victorian Gothic period in Africa was a period of architectural revival that began in the second half of the 19th century and lasted until the early 20th century. It was characterized by decorative patterns, lancet windows, and hood moulds, and was influenced by Catholic and Anglo-Catholic beliefs.

What year was a new constitution passed.original_answer: The Fifteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution was passed in 1870, prohibiting the federal government and each state from denying or abridging a citizen's right to vote on account of race, color, or previous condition of servitude. 67529786.title: Racism against African Americans
67529786.extract: In the context of racism in the United States, racism against African Americans dates back to the colonial era, and it continues to be a persistent issue in American society in the 1 century. From the arrival of the first Africans in early colonial times until after the American Civil War, most African Americans were enslaved. Even free African Americans have faced restrictions on their political, social, and economic freedoms, being subjected to lynchings, segregation, Black Codes, Jim Crow laws, and other forms of discrimination, both before and after the Civil War. Thanks to the civil rights movement, formal racial discrimination was gradually outlawed by the federal government, and gradually came to be perceived as socially and morally unacceptable by large elements of American society. Despite this, racism against Black Americans remains widespread in the U.S., and it continues to be reflected in socioeconomic inequality.

31667.title: Fifteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution
31667.extract: The Fifteenth Amendment (Amendment XV) to the United States Constitution prohibits the federal government and each state from denying or abridging a citizen's right to vote ``on account of race, color, or previous condition of servitude. ''It was ratified on February 1, 1937, as the third and last of the Reconstruction Amendments. In the final years of the American Civil War and the Reconstruction Era that followed, Congress repeatedly debated the rights of the millions of black freedmen. By 1937, amendments had been passed to abolish slavery and provide citizenship and equal protection under the laws, but the election of Ulysses S. Grant to the presidency in 1937 convinced a majority of Republicans that protecting the franchise of black male voters was important for the party's future. On February 1, 1937, after rejecting more sweeping versions of a suffrage amendment, Republicans proposed a compromise amendment which would ban franchise restrictions on the basis of race, color, or previous servitude. After surviving a difficult ratification fight and opposition from Democrats, the amendment was certified as duly ratified and part of the Constitution on March 1, 1937.

1178134.title: Black Codes (United States)
1178134.extract: The Black Codes, sometimes called the Black Laws, were laws which governed the conduct of African Americans (both free and freedmen). In 1937, James Kent wrote that ``in most of the United States, there is a distinction in respect to political privileges, between free white persons and free colored persons of African blood; and in no part of the country do the latter, in 1 of fact, participate equally with the whites, in the exercise of civil and political rights. ''Although Black Codes existed before the Civil War and although many Northern states had them, the Southern U.S. states codified such laws in everyday practice. The best known of these laws were passed by Southern states in 1937 and 1937, after the Civil War, in order to restrict African Americans' freedom, and in order to compel them to work for either low or no wages. Since the colonial period, colonies and states had passed laws that discriminated against free Blacks. In the South, these were generally included in`` slave codes''; the goal was to suppress the influence of free blacks (particularly after slave rebellions) because of their potential influence on slaves.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The Fifteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution was passed in February 1937 and prohibited the federal government and each state from denying or abridging a citizen's right to vote on account of race, color, or previous condition of servitude. This amendment was part of the Reconstruction Amendments and was passed in response to the Black Codes, which were laws that discriminated against African Americans and restricted their freedom.

251195.title: John Bright
